item.title: List of humanoid aliens
item.description:
List of Humanoid Aliens ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry is a compilation of fictional extraterrestrial humanoid characters from various media. It emphasizes that these aliens possess human-like traits such as upright posture, bipedalism, opposable thumbs, and facial features. The list is organized by medium: Animation, Comics, Film, Literature, Television, and Video Games. Each entry includes the character’s name, origin (the work in which they appear), and brief notes about their role or characteristics. The article is flagged as needing additional citations for verification and may not be complete.

Animation ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens featured in animated works. Key characters include:

  • The Great Gazoo (The Flintstones): A tiny alien exiled to Earth who can only be seen by Fred, Barney, children, and animals.
  • Cure Princess/Hime Shirayuki (HappinessCharge PreCure!): A princess from the Blue Sky Kingdom.
  • Mikitaka Hazekura (JoJo’s Bizarre Adventure): An alien who appears as a teenage boy with pointed ears.
  • Interplanet Janet (Schoolhouse Rock): A cyborg girl from another galaxy.
  • Jet Propulsion (Ready Jet Go!): An alien from Bortron 7 studying Earth.
  • Cure Milky/Lala Hagoromo (Star Twinkle PreCure): An alien from the planet Samaan.
  • Little Twelvetoes (Schoolhouse Rock): A jovial alien with green skin and six fingers and toes.
  • Marvin the Martian (Looney Tunes): A Martian often accompanied by his dog K-9.
  • Ozmodiar (The Simpsons): A parody of The Great Gazoo, only visible to Homer Simpson.
  • Roger (American Dad!): An alien living in Stan’s attic.
  • Sailor Starlights (Sailor Moon): Sailor Guardians from Planet Kinmoku.
  • Shadow Galactica (Sailor Moon): Antagonists from various planets in the Milky Way.
  • Son Goku (Dragon Ball): A Saiyan from Planet Vegeta.
  • Cure Cosmo/Yuni (Star Twinkle PreCure): A shapeshifting catgirl from Planet Rainbow.
  • Zim (Invader Zim): An Irken invader sent to conquer Earth.
  • Upgrade (Ben 10): A Galvanic Mechamorph from Galvan B.
  • Atomix (Ben 10): An alien from an unknown planet who can create nuclear energy.

Comics ðŸ”—

This section details humanoid aliens from comic books. Notable entries include:

  • Annihilus (Fantastic Four): A villain from the Marvel Universe. Created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby.
  • Cosmo (Cosmo the Merry Martian): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Bob White.
  • Darna (Darna): An extraterrestrial warrior who manifests in a human girl. Created by Mars Ravelo and Nestor Redondo.
  • KhÃ¢ny (Yoko Tsuno): An alien from the planet Vinea. Created by Roger Leloup.
  • Plunk (Plunk): An alien from the planet Smurk. Created by Luc Cromheecke and Laurent Letzer.
  • The Scrameustache (Scrameustache): An alien with a cat-like face. Created by Roland Goossens (Gos).
  • Mr. Skygack (Mr. Skygack, from Mars): A Martian studying human behavior. Created by A.D. Condo.
  • Superman/Clark Kent (Action Comics #1): An alien from Krypton with superhuman powers. Created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster.
  • Xal-Kor (Xal-Kor the Human Cat): An alien from Felis who can transform between cat, hybrid, and human forms. Created by Grass Green.
  • Zook (Zook): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Jack Miller and Joe Certa.

Film ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens appearing in movies. Key examples include:

  • E.T. (E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial): An alien who befriends a human boy.
  • Various (Marvel Cinematic Universe): Includes Asgardians, members of the Guardians of the Galaxy, and Eternals.
  • Klaatu (The Day the Earth Stood Still): An alien who delivers a peaceful message to Earth.
  • Various (Star Wars): Includes Chewbacca, Yoda, Darth Maul, and Ahsoka Tano.
  • Zaphod Beeblebrox (The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy): An alien from near Betelgeuse.
  • Mork (Mork and Mindy): An alien from Ork who studies humanity on Earth.
  • The Alien Girl (Super Deluxe): An alien living on Earth, mingling with humans.

Literature ðŸ”—

This section compiles humanoid aliens from literary works. Notable characters include:

  • The Little Prince (The Little Prince): A prince from an asteroid who visits Earth.
  • Curtis (One Door Away from Heaven): A shape-shifting alien on the run.
  • Ras Thavas (The Master Mind of Mars): A Martian mad scientist.
  • The Thing (Who Goes There?): A shapeshifting alien that takes a human form.

Television ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens featured in television shows. Key characters include:

  • Adric (Doctor Who): A young native of Alzarius in E-Space.
  • ALF/Gordon Shumway (ALF): An alien from Melmac who crash lands on Earth.
  • Beldar, Prymaat, and Connie (Coneheads): An alien family from Remulak with conical heads.
  • Big Giant Head (3rd Rock from the Sun): The alien leader of the Solomons.
  • The Doctor (Doctor Who): An adventurer and scientist.
  • FofÃ£o (BalÃ£o MÃ¡gico and TV FofÃ£o): An extraterrestrial child character.
  • Gonzo (The Muppet Show): A puppet revealed to be of extraterrestrial origin.
  • Mork (Mork & Mindy): An alien from Ork who befriends a human woman.
  • Martin O’Hara (My Favorite Martian): A Martian anthropologist stranded on Earth.
  • Dick Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Harry Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Sally Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Tommy Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Spock (Star Trek): A Vulcan science officer on the Enterprise.
  • Ultraman (Ultraman): A race of aliens who protect the universe.
  • Ultronians (My Hero): A species from the planet Ultron with superpowers.

Video Games ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens appearing in video games. Key examples include:

  • Abe (Oddworld): The central character of the Oddworld series.
  • Artanis (StarCraft): A Protoss commander and protagonist.
  • Forerunner (Halo): Ancient Humanoid Aliens that created the Halo rings.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_humanoid_aliens

item.title: List of alien races in Marvel Comics
item.description:
List of Alien Races in Marvel Comics ðŸ”—

This document provides a comprehensive list of alien races that appear in Marvel Comics. It is organized alphabetically and includes both major and secondary races, along with their key characteristics and appearances.

Contents ðŸ”—

This section simply lists the letters of the alphabet, serving as a quick index to find alien races by their starting letter.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section establishes that the Marvel Comics universe contains a vast number of extraterrestrial races, most of which are humanoid.

Galactic Council ðŸ”—

This section introduces the Galactic Council, an assembly of leaders from various alien empires. It was created to address universal matters.

Current members ðŸ”—

This lists the current members of the Galactic Council, including representatives from the Kree/Skrull Alliance (Kl’rt/Paibok), Shi’ar Empire (Oracle-2/Izzy Kane), Utopian Kree (Noh-Varr), Earth/Nova Corps (Richard Rider), Spartax (Empress Victoria/Peter Quill), Rigellians (Mentacle), Kymellians (Nymbis Sternhoof), Wakanda (Riitho), Galactic Rim Collective (Zoralis Gupa/Orbis Stellaris), Badoon Sisterhood (Lani Ko Ako), Chitauri Empire (Peacebringer), and Zn’rx Empire (Empress Kuga).

Former members ðŸ”—

This lists former members of the Galactic Council, including representatives from Asgard (Freyja), Brotherhood of the Badoon (Y-Gaaar), Kree Empire (Supreme Intelligence/Ronan the Accuser), Negative Zone (Annihilus), Axi-Tun (Alberik), Shi’ar Empire (Majestor/Lilandra), Badoon (Manat), Brood (Brood Queen), Inhuman Royal Family (Gorgon/Medusa/Crystal/Karnak), Ruul/Kree Empire (Kronaster Sintariis), Kree/Skrull Alliance (Captain Val-Lorr), Krylorians (Bartos), Kymellians (Fayrelyte Strongheart), Negative Zone (Blastaar), Planet X (Groot), Rigellians (Nelet Pa), Skrull Empire (Kreddik), Sneepers (Dibdeb), Stonians (Basaltar), Wobbow (Wibbow), Spartax (J’son), Zn’rx (Emperor Stote), and Chitauri (Peacemaker).

In other media ðŸ”—

This section notes the Galactic Council’s appearance in the Guardians of the Galaxy animated series, with members including J’son, Thor, Irani Rael, the Rigellian Grand Commissioner, and the Supreme Intelligence.

Major races ðŸ”—

This section introduces alien races that have had significant presence in Marvel Comics publications, including major crossovers and storylines.

Badoon ðŸ”—

The Badoon are reptilian aliens known for strict gender segregation, resulting in the Brotherhood of Badoon (ruled by a “Brother Royal”) and the Sisterhood of Badoon (ruled by a Queen). They first appeared in Silver Surfer #2.

Beyonders ðŸ”—

The Beyonders are enigmatic, virtually omnipotent entities powerful enough to collect planets. They cannot leave their dimension and operate through agents. The Beyonder is the most notable member. They were first mentioned in Marvel Two-in-One #63.

Brood ðŸ”—

The Brood are a race of insectoid, parasitic, extraterrestrial beings. They first appeared in The Uncanny X-Men #155.

Celestials ðŸ”—

The Celestials have existed since near the birth of the universe. They first appeared in The Eternals #1.

Chitauri ðŸ”—

The Chitauri are aliens similar to the Skrulls in the Ultimate Marvel universe. They have since been established in the main Marvel Universe. They first appeared in The Ultimates #8.

Cotati ðŸ”—

The Cotati are a race of highly intelligent, telepathic plants originating on Hala, the same planet as the Kree. They first appeared in The Avengers #133.

Dire Wraiths ðŸ”—

The Dire Wraiths are an evolutionary offshoot of the Skrulls from the Andromeda Galaxy. Like the Skrulls, they are shapeshifters. They first appeared in Rom the Spaceknight #1.

Kree ðŸ”—

The Kree are a scientifically and technologically advanced militaristic alien race native to the planet Hala. They were the rivals of the Skrulls. They first appeared in Fantastic Four #65.

Phalanx ðŸ”—

The Phalanx are a cybernetic species that form a hive-mind. They first appeared in The Uncanny X-Men #305.

Shi’ar ðŸ”—

The Shi’ar are alien humanoids of avian descent residing in the Shi’ar Empire. Their empire is a vast collection of alien species, cultures, and worlds. They first appeared in X-Men #97.

Skrulls ðŸ”—

The Skrulls are a race of shapeshifting aliens originating from the planet Skrullos. They were the rivals of the Kree. They first appeared in Fantastic Four #2.

Symbiotes ðŸ”—

The Symbiotes are amorphous extraterrestrial parasites that envelop their hosts like costumes, creating a symbiotic bond. They are also known as the Klyntar. They first appeared in Secret Wars #8.

Watchers ðŸ”—

The Watchers are the first humanoid race created in the Marvel Universe. They observe and compile knowledge on all aspects of the universe but have vowed not to interfere. Uatu is the most known Watcher. They first appeared in Fantastic Four #13.

Secondary races ðŸ”—

This section lists a multitude of other extraterrestrial races that have appeared in Marvel Comics, though not as prominently as the major races.

A ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races starting with the letter “A”.

A’askvarii ðŸ”—

The A’askvarii are a green-skinned humanoid race with octopus traits from the oceanic planet O’erlanii. They first appeared in Black Goliath.

A-Chiltarians ðŸ”—

The A-Chiltarians are a purple-grey furred humanoid race with many eyes from the marshy planet A-Chiltar III. Kraglin is an A-Chiltarian. They first appeared in Tales to Astonish.

Aakon ðŸ”—

The Aakon are a yellow-skinned, dark-haired humanoid race and enemies of the Kree. They are allied with the Shadow Consortium. They first appeared in Captain Marvel.

Acanti ðŸ”—

The Acanti are a race of space creatures that resemble whales. They first appeared in The Uncanny X-Men.

Achernonians ðŸ”—

The Achernonians are a purple-skinned humanoid race from the rocky planet Achernon. They are depicted as superstitious and have a dictatorial government. Some can become immaterial. They first appeared in Thor.

Aedians ðŸ”—

The Aedians are thin humanoid bipeds with elongated craniums and no noses. They possess telepathic and empathic powers and can project their astral selves. They first appeared in Silver Surfer.

Agullo ðŸ”—

The Agullo are an alien race that was diminished from over 60,000,000 to a few thousands after Thanos came to their planet Ahl-Agullo.

Alpha Centaurians ðŸ”—

The Alpha Centaurians are a humanoid race with grey scales adapted for underwater living from the planet Arima. They have a feudal government and are capable of near-lightspeed travel. They first appeared in Sub-Mariner.

Amebids ðŸ”—

The Amebids are a race of jellyfish-like aliens that come from the planet Sakaar.

Annunaki ðŸ”—

The Annunaki are an alien race that helped Silver Surfer gather and protect some of Earth’s most extraordinary gifted children.

Archeopians ðŸ”—

The Archeopians are from the planet Archeopia. Most of the race was killed when the incubator cube of Galactus was opened and he consumed Archeopia.

Arcturans ðŸ”—

The Arcturans are a pink-white skinned humanoid race from Arcturus IV. A significant portion of their population are mutants. Starhawk and Aleta are Arcturans. They first appeared in Fear.

Aris ðŸ”—

The Aris are an alien race that comes from the planet Ariston.

Arthrosians ðŸ”—

The Arthrosians are a race of insectoids that come from the planet Anthros in the Negative Zone. Annihilus is an Arthrosian.

Aspirants ðŸ”—

The Aspirants are a race of celestial beings that were the result of the First Firmament’s loneliness.

Astrans ðŸ”—

The Astrans are a yellow-skinned humanoid race with flat feet from the planet Astra. They can control metal and are mostly priests or artists. They first appeared in The Incredible Hulk.

Astrans in other media ðŸ”—

The Astrans appear in Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.

Ataraxians ðŸ”—

The Ataraxians are a race of aliens from the planet Ataraxia in the Negative Zone.

Autocrons ðŸ”—

The Autocrons are a blue-black skinned humanoid race with iron-based bodies from the planet Cron. They possess superhuman strength and durability and have an imperialistic, militaristic culture ruled by a world-computer

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_alien_races_in_Marvel_Comics

item.title: List of alien races in DC Comics
item.description:
List of Alien Races in DC Comics ðŸ”—

This is a comprehensive list of extraterrestrial races that have appeared in DC Comics, including comic books and other media. It provides brief descriptions and citations for each race.

Overview ðŸ”—

The DC Comics universe contains a vast number of alien races, most of which are humanoid.

United Planets ðŸ”—

The United Planets is a governing body active from the 21st to the 31st centuries. Members include planets of the Solar System, Htrae, artificial planet-sized satellites, buffer planets seeded by Mon-El, and neighboring empires. In the 21st century, the United Planets are led by the corrupt Durlan Thaaros.

0-9 ðŸ”—

5th Dimensional Imps ðŸ”—

Zrfff is the homeworld of 5th Dimensional Imps, including Mister Mxyzptlk, Miss Gsptlsnz, Vyndktvx, Brpxz, Mister Genie (Genro), Quisp, Bat-Mite, Kcid Nosyarg (Larry), Zook, Gazook, and Mopee. In other media, 5th Dimensional Imps appear in Supergirl, consisting of Mxyzptlk and Gsptlsnz / Nyxlygsptlnz. The Music Meister is revealed to be an imp in a Supergirl crossover with The Flash.

A ðŸ”—

Adaptoids ðŸ”—

The Adaptoids are blob-like creatures from the vicinity of Arcturus that attempted to wipe out the human race on Earth-One. They were defeated by the Justice League when exposed to the Thanagarian equalizing disease.

Aellans ðŸ”—

The Aellans are yellow-skinned reptilian humanoids from Aello (Stormswift), Demonia, Harpis, and Doc of Aello were all members of the Omega Men.

Alien Invaders ðŸ”—

The Alien Invaders are the nameless primary antagonists of Armageddon: The Alien Agenda.

Almeraci ðŸ”—

The Almeraci are a humanoid race of technologically advanced warriors with psionic abilities, ruled by the House of the Blood Royale, a matriarchy of superpowered monarchs. They choose mates through ceremonial gladiatorial competitions. Maxima, Queen of Almerac, her handmaiden Sazu, and her onetime betrothed Ultraa represent this species.

Aloi ðŸ”—

The Aloi are blue-skinned aliens with ridged foreheads at war with the Margoi over a device known as the “Grayl”. Tumlat represents them.

Alstairans ðŸ”—

The Alstairans of Alstair are plantlike humanoids with leaves instead of hair, one of four technologically advanced spacefaring races native to the Antares system. Their ruler is the alien plant elemental Hyathis.

Anasazi ðŸ”—

The Anasazi are metahumans resettled to planet Starhaven, represented by Dawnstar.

Andromedans ðŸ”—

The Andromedans of the Andromeda Galaxy are a race of superhumans similar to Kryptonians and Daxamites, with red hair, albino skin, and blue eyes. Karb-Brak was exiled to Earth and later cured by Superman and Vartox.

Angtuans ðŸ”—

The Angtuans are inhabitants of the planet Angtu, a world with a thick, noxious atmosphere. Angtu was destroyed in the 30th century by the mutated native Mano.

Anunnake ðŸ”—

The Anunnake are reptilian aliens who claim to have killed off the dinosaurs; they are also known as the Hunter/Gatherers.

Anndrann ðŸ”—

The Anndrann are green-skinned military geniuses from Anndranna, later banished to Bellatrix, famed for their weapons of war. Iron has a deleterious effect on their cognitive abilities.

Appellaxians ðŸ”—

The Appellaxians of Appellax are technologically advanced energy aliens with the ability to create powerful artificial host bodies for their minds. The seven Appellaxians that invaded created bodies named Golden Roc, Wood King, Stone-God, Crystal Creature, Fire-Lord, Glass-Man, and Mercury Monster. The Justice League first came together because of them. In Young Justice, Bruno Mannheim combines them into a Golem using a Mother Box, before it is destroyed by Black Beetle.

Aipitons ðŸ”—

The Aipitons are the presumed name of a species of small flying insects of the planet Apaiton, represented by the deceased Green Lantern Bzzd.

Aquoids ðŸ”—

The Aquoids are natives of planet Beltair IV.

Aranes ðŸ”—

The Aranes of Arane II are light blue-skinned, white-haired humanoids with tiny blue protruding horns on their foreheads. Rolind Siepur of Arane II is a member of the Dark Circle.

Ardenans ðŸ”—

The Ardenans are the presumed name of a sentient race of humanoids with orange scaly skin from the planet Arden, represented by the deceased Green Lanterns Lodar and Meeno Monak.

Astonians ðŸ”—

The Astonians are a minor alien race under a once dying star saved by the Blue Lantern Saint Walker upon facing extinction. Saint Walker is of this race.

Azarathians ðŸ”—

The Azarathians are people belonging to the parallel universe of Azarath. Raven is an Azarathian.

B ðŸ”—

Barrions ðŸ”—

The Barrions of Barrio III are silicon-based lifeforms, represented by the Green Lantern Chaselon.

Bellatrix Bombers ðŸ”—

The Bellatrix Bombers are alien warlords featured in Green Lantern (vol. 3) #20.

Bgztlians ðŸ”—

The Bgztlians are humans from the colony Bgztl who possess the metahuman ability of intangibility. Phantom Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes is their representative.

Blight ðŸ”—

The Blight are a cybernetic race whose bodies are composed of rotting flesh and villains of the Legion of Super-Heroes. Their leader is Atrophos.

Bloodline Parasites ðŸ”—

The eight Bloodline Parasites were extraterrestrial lifeforms capable of accidentally activating the human metagene during the act of feeding on human spinal fluid.

Braalians ðŸ”—

The Braalians are humans from the colony Braal who possess the metahuman ability of electromagnetic field manipulation. Cosmic Boy and Magno of the Legion of Super-Heroes are their representatives.

Brain-Parasites of Planet X ðŸ”—

The Brain-Parasites of Planet X hail from Planet X and use powerful Knowledge-Extractors to steal knowledge from other races.

Branx ðŸ”—

The Branx of Emana Branx are a gray-skinned race of dull-witted, four-armed warriors who serve the Citadelians.

Brylyx ðŸ”—

The Brylyx are white-skinned aliens featured in Green Lantern: Mosaic.

The Bolovax Vikians ðŸ”—

The Bolovax Vikians are highly communal and technologically advanced. Bolovax Vikians of Bolovax Vik are a dead race. Kilowog of the Green Lantern Corps is the last surviving member of this species. A holographic Bolovax Vikian appears in the My Adventures with Superman episode “The Machine Who Would Be Empire”.

Bugs of New Genesis ðŸ”—

The Bugs of New Genesis are an insectoid race who were spread on New Genesis during their war with Apokolips. Forager and Mantis are the most prominent members of the race.

C ðŸ”—

Cairnians ðŸ”—

The Cairnians are members of L.E.G.I.O.N.

Calatonians ðŸ”—

The Calatonians are an ancient monarchy on the planet Calaton ravaged by the Doomsday creature.

Canopians ðŸ”—

The Canopians are a member of Atari Force. Canopians such as Morphea are from New Earth in a parallel universe.

Carggites ðŸ”—

The Carggites are humans from the colony Cargg who possess the metahuman ability of duplication. Triplicate Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes is their representative.

Catherix ðŸ”—

The Cathexis are a race of alien super-scientists from the “sixth dimension” who created self-aware reality endangering technology.

Changralynians ðŸ”—

The Changralynians of Changralyn are a race of silicon-based pacifists, they are represented by Broot of the Omega Men.

Children of Tanjent ðŸ”—

The Children of Tanjent are a psionic race.

Circadians ðŸ”—

The peaceful insectoid Circadians of Circadia established a joint human/Circadian settlement in the 30th Century known as Pax Colony. Circadia Senius is a Chronarch Research Fellow at the Metropolis Time Institute and a friend of Brainiac 5.

Citadelians ðŸ”—

The Citadelians of the Citadel are a race of sadistic imperialistic clones, whose intellect and genetic viability degrades with each newly cloned generation.

Clementians ðŸ”—

The Clementians of Clementia are also known as “Black Mercies”. The Green Lantern Mother Mercy is the caretaker and ruler of the Clementian race.

Coluans ðŸ”—

The Coluans (sometimes known as Yod-Colu) of Colu are a hyper-intelligent species, one of the most technologically advanced in the known universe. They are most notably represented by the various men and women who hold the title of Brainiac along with Pulsar Stargrave. The planet Colu was destroyed by the Omega Titans in Justice League: No Justice. The Coluans appear in *

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanagarian

item.title: Lists of fictional extraterrestrials
item.description:
Lists of Fictional Extraterrestrial Species ðŸ”—

This page serves as a central index for various lists cataloging fictional extraterrestrial species found across different media. It also provides links to related topics like fictional species in general.

Alphabetical ðŸ”—

This section provides a comprehensive alphabetical listing of links to individual pages, each dedicated to fictional alien species whose names begin with a specific letter of the alphabet. This allows users to quickly navigate to species based on their name. For example, there are links for A, B, C, and so on, up to Z.

By Medium & Franchise ðŸ”—

This section organizes lists of fictional extraterrestrial species based on the specific medium or franchise in which they appear.

Literature ðŸ”—

  • List of Noon Universe alien races: Links to the section on alien races within the Noon Universe, a science fiction setting created by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky.

Comics ðŸ”—

  • List of alien races in DC Comics: Directs to a list of alien species featured in publications by DC Comics.
  • List of alien races in Marvel Comics: Directs to a list of alien species featured in publications by Marvel Comics.

Film and Television ðŸ”—

  • List of Doctor Who universe creatures and aliens: Links to a comprehensive list of creatures and aliens appearing in the Doctor Who franchise.
  • List of Star Trek aliens: Links to a list of alien species from the Star Trek universe.
  • List of Star Wars creatures: Links to a list of creatures from the Star Wars universe.
  • Lists of Star Wars species: Provides a breakdown of Star Wars species lists, divided alphabetically:
    • Aâ€“E
    • Fâ€“J
    • Kâ€“O
    • Pâ€“T
    • Uâ€“Z
  • Species of the Marvel Cinematic Universe: Links to a list of species appearing in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

Games ðŸ”—

  • Battlelords of the 23rd Century#Races: Links to the section detailing alien races in the Battlelords of the 23rd Century role-playing game.
  • Races of Mass Effect: Links to a list of the various alien races featured in the Mass Effect video game series.
  • Races of StarCraft: Links to a list of the various alien races featured in the StarCraft video game series.

By Appearance ðŸ”—

This section categorizes alien species based on their physical characteristics.

  • List of humanoid aliens: Links to a list of alien species that resemble humans in their basic body plan.
  • List of reptilian humanoids: Links to a list of humanoid aliens that possess reptilian features.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to other relevant lists and templates related to fictional life forms and science fiction in general. It includes a comprehensive table linking to lists of fictional plants, animals (categorized by type), humanoids, and other creatures, as well as templates for fictional biology and science fiction topics.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fictional_extraterrestrials

item.title: Joe Alien
item.description:
Joe Alien ðŸ”—

Joe Alien is a British comic book character who appeared in strips published by Fleetway Publications. He debuted in the preview issue of the science fiction anthology Wildcat in October 1988. The character’s strip was one of four linked serials in Wildcat and was later briefly featured in Eagle after Wildcat was canceled. Joe Alien is the last survivor of the planet Xgangbe-4 and joins the Wildcat mission to help humanity find a new home, commanding the Wildcat 2 exploration shuttle.

Creation ðŸ”—

Barrie Tomlinson created Joe Alien as part of a new science fiction anthology, Wildcat, for Fleetway Publications. The concept involved linking all five features in the comic to form an overall narrative centered on the spaceship Wildcat. Tomlinson created four lead characters, including Joe Alien, to head exploration teams. Massimo Belardinelli was the initial artist for “Joe Alien,” with Tomlinson praising his ability to bring the story to life.

Publishing history ðŸ”—

Wildcat began publication in October 1988, featuring “Joe Alien” as the color strip. Ron Smith took over as the artist from the third issue. Wildcat was canceled after 12 issues and merged with Eagle in March 1989. “Joe Alien” continued in Eagle for four weeks in May 1989 to complete the story arc and also featured in three episodes of “The Wildcat Complete” anthology. Rebellion Developments purchased the rights to Wildcat in 2016 and announced plans to reprint the contents in collected editions. As of 2025, only “Turbo Jones” and “Loner” have been released.

Plot summary ðŸ”—

Joe Alien joins the Wildcat mission after Turbo Jones realizes Earth is doomed. Joe, the last survivor of Xgangbe-4, possesses vast knowledge stored in an external brain-pack. He is selected for his intelligence and physical attributes. After the Wildcat launches, Joe’s sensors locate a potential new home for the refugees.

He leads the Wildcat Two shuttle to scout Area 17, where his team encounters carnivorous vegetation and a two-headed alien. They discover that the plants are controlled by a mad human astronaut from a 2079 Mars mission, who is now worshipped as a god. Joe brokers an alliance with giant insects to escape and later participates in other expeditions.

Joe shares the story of the Xgangbe’s destruction by the Kargroz and his revenge. He is later chosen to find an alien shapeshifter on board the Wildcat. Joe, along with Jones, Loner, and Magee, is kidnapped by a Gamemaster of the Glarzon race but is released after defeating the Glarzon’s troops.

Reception ðŸ”—

Graham Kibble-White described Joe Alien as “dopily designed.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Alien
